questions.text:
A 62-year-old man with limited, unresectable small cell lung cancer comes to the emergency department because of fever for the past 2 days. He has been on numerous chemotherapy regimens. His last round of treatment was with cisplatin and etoposide and ended 10 days ago. He feels fatigued but has not had nausea or vomiting. He appears ill. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 115/min, and blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dry mucous membranes. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
10.2 g/dL


Leukocyte count
4000/mm3



 Total neutrophils

8%


 Eosinophils
2%


 Lymphocytes
80%


 Monocytes
10%


Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Blood culture samples are obtained. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Cefepime therapy
Fluconazole therapy
Piperacillin therapy
Clindamycin therapy
Bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage
High-resolution CT scan of the chest
Measurement of serum fungal markers

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In neutropenia, the neutrophil-mediated inflammatory response to bacterial infections is impaired. The risk of serious infection is directly associated with the extent and duration of neutropenia. To minimize the risk of mortality, patients with neutropenic fever should be given immediate empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics after blood cultures are taken (in addition to cultures having been taken from any suspected site of infection). IV therapy with an antipseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic (e.g., cefepime, meropenem, piperacillin/tazobactam, imipenem/cilastatin) that covers both gram-negative and gram-positive bacteria is recommended for patients at high risk (e.g., patients with hematologic malignancy and previous fungal infection). Vancomycin should be added for patients with risk factors for MRSA (e.g., indwelling catheters). Patients at low risk who can tolerate oral intake and who have a caregiver may be treated with oral antipseudomonal antibiotics (e.g., levofloxacin PLUS amoxicillin/clavulanate) on an outpatient basis.

If the fever persists 72 hours after the initiation of antibiotic treatment, the patient should be reassessed for fungal or viral infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluconazole is the drug of choice for cryptococcal meningitis (in patients with AIDS), candidiasis (all forms), and coccidioidomycosis. Patients with immunodeficiency (e.g., those undergoing chemotherapy) are at increased risk of developing fungal infections. However, bacteria are the most frequent cause of infection in patients with neutropenia because the neutrophil-mediated inflammatory response to bacterial infections is impaired. After blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken, patients with neutropenic fever must receive empiric antibiotic treatment before potential fungal infections are addressed.

C) INCORRECT:

After blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken, a patient with neutropenic fever must receive empiric antibiotic treatment. Piperacillin has a broad range of antibacterial properties that include gram-negative bacilli (including Pseudomonas aeruginosa), gram-positive cocci, and anaerobic pathogens. However, piperacillin is not effective against organisms that produce beta-lactamases (e.g., penicillinase-producing Staphylococcus aureus). This antibiotic would, therefore, only be appropriate for this patient if administered in combination with tazobactam.

D) INCORRECT:

After blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken, patients with neutropenic fever must receive empiric antibiotic treatment. Clindamycin is effective against anaerobic bacteria and certain gram-positive organisms such as methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA). However, it does not cover Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is one of the most commonly identified pathogens in patients with neutropenia.

E) INCORRECT:

In this patient, bronchoscopy could be useful for the detection of bronchopulmonary infection. However, after blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken, patients with neutropenic fever should receive immediate treatment prior to undergoing other diagnostic procedures.

F) INCORRECT:

In this patient, a high-resolution chest CT may be useful for the detection of pulmonary infection, as well as for the evaluation of tumor response to chemotherapy. However, after blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken, patients with neutropenic fever should receive immediate treatment prior to undergoing other diagnostic procedures.

G) INCORRECT:

Patients with immunodeficiency (e.g., those undergoing chemotherapy) are at increased risk of developing fungal infections. However, bacteria are the most frequent cause of infection in patients with neutropenia because the neutrophil-mediated inflammatory response to bacterial infections is impaired. Patients with neutropenic fever must receive immediate empiric treatment after blood cultures and other relevant samples (e.g., urine cultures) are taken and prior to initiating other diagnostic tests.
questions.hint: This patient, who recently underwent chemotherapy, has a fever of > 38.3°C (101°F) and an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of < 500 cells/μL (ANC = WBC x [total percentage of neutrophils/100]), which is sufficient for a diagnosis of neutropenic fever.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man receiving chemotherapy for extensive-stage small-cell lung cancer is due for a midcycle toxicity check when he notices that his temperature is 38.5°C. He presents to the emergency department, reporting only the fever and mild fatigue.
His current treatment involves carboplatin and etoposide. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension.
Physical examination is notable for a heart rate of 72 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 128/72 mm Hg. His chest is clear, and his abdomen is benign. A port is in place, with no erythema or discharge at the insertion site.
His absolute neutrophil count, which was normal one week ago, is now 100 cells per mm3 (reference range, 1900–7600). Liver and kidney function tests are normal. A chest radiograph shows an unchanged central mass, with no evidence of pneumonia. Urinalysis is normal; blood and urine cultures are pending.
What is the most appropriate next step in managing this case?

choices.text: After a brief period of observation, discharge with oral ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate, and follow up the next day
Admit for observation, remove the implanted port and catheter as a suspected infection source, and start intravenous (IV) vancomycin, high-dose IV cefepime, and IV fluconazole
Discharge without antibiotics and leave a message with his oncologist to follow up on his culture data
Admit for observation and initiate broad-spectrum antipseudomonal coverage with high-dose intravenous piperacillin-tazobactam
Admit for observation and initiate empiric broad-spectrum therapy with intravenous (IV) vancomycin, high-dose IV cefepime, and IV fluconazole

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Febrile neutropenia is a common oncologic occurrence that often prompts visits to the emergency department. Appropriate management depends on whether the fever is high-risk or low-risk. Low-risk neutropenic fever is characterized by an expected duration of neutropenia of 7 days or less, no evidence of sepsis syndrome, no coexisting conditions, and no evidence of hepatic or renal dysfunction. Two large, randomized clinical trials have demonstrated that patients with low-risk neutropenic fever and established outpatient care can be safely discharged on an oral combination of a fluoroquinolone and a beta-lactam (such as the combination of ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate). The safety of oral cephalosporin monotherapy has not been established in randomized trials.

Key learning point: A patient with low-risk neutropenia (i.e., neutropenia that lasts no more than 7 to 10 days in the absence of other underlying conditions) and fever can be managed with ciprofloxacin and amoxicillin-clavulanate.

B) INCORRECT:

Hospital admission is unnecessary and therefore not the best management decision.

C) INCORRECT:

Discharge without antibiotics is not appropriate.

D) INCORRECT:

Hospital admission is unnecessary and therefore not the best management decision.

E) INCORRECT:

Hospital admission is unnecessary and therefore not the best management decision.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a purpuric rash. He recently completed induction chemotherapy with daunorubicin plus cytarabine for acute myelogenous leukemia.
Upon evaluation, he is arousable and states that he feels extremely tired. His temperature is 40.1°C, his heart rate is 110 beats per minute, and his blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. A purpuric plaque with ulceration is present on his thigh (figure).
Laboratory testing reveals an absolute neutrophil count of 245 per mm3 (reference range, 1900–7600).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?

choices.text: Sweet syndrome
Pyoderma gangrenosum
Leukemia cutis
Calciphylaxis
Ecthyma gangrenosum

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Sweet syndrome is associated with acute myelogenous leukemia and certain medications, such as colony-stimulating factors. It usually manifests as edematous, red, or violaceous plaques and nodules. Although both pyoderma gangrenosum and Sweet syndrome can manifest with ulcerated violaceous plaques, neither condition is likely to cause the hypotension seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyoderma gangrenosum and Sweet syndrome are neutrophilic dermatoses characterized by sterile infiltration of neutrophils into the dermis. Pyoderma gangrenosum manifests as an ulcer with a rolled purple border and may exhibit pathergy, but it is not commonly associated with neutropenic sepsis.

C) INCORRECT:

Leukemia cutis is characterized by violaceous to purpuric papules, plaques, and nodules on the skin and oral mucosa. These lesions rarely ulcerate and become necrotic. Leukemia cutis can occur at any time during the course of leukemia but would be uncommon shortly after induction chemotherapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Calciphylaxis manifests as purpuric patches with firm, indurated surrounding plaques, usually in areas of increased adipose tissue. It is most often associated with end-stage kidney disease.

E) CORRECT:

Ecthyma gangrenosum is a skin infection often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa bacteremia. Other gram-negative rods, fungal species, and Staphylococcus aureus are less commonly involved but have also been reported. Patients with ecthyma gangrenosum present with a purpuric patch, most often on the buttocks and thighs, with overlying necrosis and eventual eschar formation. Early detection and prompt initiation of therapy against P. aeruginosa is imperative.

Key learning point: In a neutropenic patient who presents with sepsis and necrotic purpuric plaques on the thighs and/or buttocks, an important infection to consider is ecthyma gangrenosum (Pseudomonas aeruginosa septicemia).

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man who was recently diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma presents to the emergency department reporting a 48-hour history of fever, cough, and abdominal pain. He started his first cycle of chemotherapy — doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD regimen) — 10 days ago.
He has a temperature of 39°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/75 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A complete blood count shows an absolute neutrophil count of 100 cells per mm3 (reference range, 1900–7600).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Administer acetaminophen and reassess body temperature in one hour
Start empiric antibiotics and administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
Obtain two sets of blood cultures and an abdominal plain-film radiograph
Obtain two sets of blood cultures; start empiric antibiotics only if the blood cultures are positive
Obtain two sets of blood cultures, start empiric antibiotics, and order CT of the chest and abdomen

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen with reassessment of body temperature in one hour is not sufficient in a patient with neutropenic fever.

B) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factors are not routinely used in most patients with fever and neutropenia. These medications are reserved for use as an adjunct treatment in patients at high risk for infectious complications and in those who have prolonged fever and neutropenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain in the right lower quadrant of a patient with neutropenic fever is concerning for neutropenic enterocolitis (also known as typhlitis), an uncommon complication of cytotoxic chemotherapy that usually affects the ileocecal area. Affected patients are at risk for bowel perforation related to inflammation of the bowel wall. CT of the abdomen is the preferred imaging modality because plain-film radiographs have poor sensitivity.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics and a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation are recommended in the initial management of neutropenic fever, given the potential for rapid progression of an untreated infection in a patient with an impaired immune system. Infections are documented in 20% to 30% of episodes of neutropenic fever.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has fever in the setting of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia, thus raising concern for the possibility of infection. According to guidelines from the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA), fever is defined as either a single oral temperature ≥38.3°C or an elevation in temperature to ≥38.0°C for more than one hour, and neutropenia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count that is already <500 cells per mm3 or expected to fall below that value during the next 48 hours.

Empiric antibiotics and a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation are recommended in the initial management of neutropenic fever, given the potential for rapid progression of an untreated infection in a patient with an impaired immune system. Infections are documented in 20% to 30% of episodes of neutropenic fever.

IDSA guidelines recommend obtaining at least two sets of blood cultures in patients with neutropenic fever. Additional diagnostic evaluation with imaging studies should be guided by signs and symptoms. In this case, the patient has cough, tachypnea, and abdominal pain — and should therefore undergo chest and abdominal imaging. The most recent IDSA guidelines for patients with febrile neutropenia do not specify a preferred chest-imaging modality in patients with respiratory symptoms. Older IDSA guidelines recommend a chest radiograph in these patients; however, there is some evidence that CT may be more sensitive, and thus, it is a reasonable option in this case.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for a patient undergoing chemotherapy who presents with neutropenic fever is to obtain two sets of blood cultures, start empiric antibiotics, and order imaging studies guided by the patient's specific signs and symptoms.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman develops fever 5 days after beginning induction chemotherapy for recently diagnosed acute myeloid leukemia. She has a history of a penicillin allergy, which she describes as a mild, nonpruritic rash when she was 9 years old. She has not received any penicillins or cephalosporins since that time.
On physical examination, her temperature is 39.1°C, her heart rate is 116 beats per minute, her blood pressure is 110/62 mm Hg, and her respiratory rate is 14 breaths per minute. She has mild mucositis, normal breath sounds, a soft nontender abdomen, and an unremarkable skin examination. She has two peripheral venous catheters with no evidence of erythema or tenderness.
Laboratory evaluation reveals a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL (reference range, 12.0–16.0), a platelet count of 90,000 per mm3 (150,000–350,000), and a leukocyte count of 1100 per mm3 (4500–11,000) with an absolute neutrophil count of 200 per mm3 (1900–7600). A comprehensive metabolic panel is normal.
Which one of the following medications is the best choice for empiric antimicrobial therapy?

choices.text: Vancomycin
Aztreonam
Tobramycin
Ciprofloxacin
Cefepime

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Vancomycin monotherapy is not an appropriate treatment for neutropenic fever because of the lack of gram-negative coverage. In addition, vancomycin is not recommended as part of initial empiric antibiotic treatment of neutropenic fever unless there is evidence of skin or soft-tissue infection, pneumonia, hemodynamic instability, or suspected catheter-related infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Aztreonam monotherapy is not recommended for the treatment of neutropenic fever because it does not have any activity against gram-positive organisms, such as streptococci, which are common pathogens in neutropenic fever.

C) INCORRECT:

Tobramycin and other aminoglycosides should not be used as monotherapy for neutropenic fever because of the lack of gram-positive coverage and the risk for rapid emergence of antimicrobial resistance.

D) INCORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin monotherapy is not recommended for the treatment of high-risk neutropenic fever because it does not adequately cover gram-positive pathogens.

E) CORRECT:

This patient’s neutropenic fever should be considered high risk, given that her cytotoxic chemotherapy is expected to result in a prolonged neutropenia. Patients with high-risk neutropenic fever should receive intravenous antibiotic therapy in a hospital setting with an antipseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic (such as cefepime), a carbapenem, or piperacillin-tazobactam.

The choice of antibiotic in this case is complicated by the fact that the patient reports a penicillin allergy, thus raising concern that she could develop an allergic reaction if given penicillin or an antibiotic with cross-reactivity to penicillin. Whether the patient’s distant penicillin reaction was immunoglobulin (Ig) E mediated is not clear. Although the history is somewhat reassuring, with no concerning features such as hives, bronchospasm, angioedema, or anaphylaxis, an IgE-mediated reaction cannot be ruled out on the basis of this history alone.

Even if the original reaction were IgE mediated, the patient is very unlikely to still have IgE antibodies, as these antibody levels tend to wane with time. However, because an IgE-mediated allergic reaction can be life-threatening, penicillin skin testing should be performed before administration of any penicillin-based antibiotic, to ensure the absence of penicillin-specific IgE antibodies. If skin testing is not available, a graded challenge with the alternative penicillin is reasonable.

There is still no consensus regarding the management of a patient with a history of an IgE-mediated reaction to penicillin who subsequently requires administration of a cephalosporin. In this case, where the patient’s reaction was in the distant past and unlikely to have been IgE mediated, and the cross-reactivity between penicillin and cephalosporins is so low, administering cefepime directly is an acceptable choice if that medication is deemed to be the best therapeutic agent.

Key learning point: A patient with high-risk neutropenic fever and a childhood penicillin allergy characterized as a mild rash without hives or other evidence of an immediate-hypersensitivity reaction to penicillin should be treated with an antipseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotic.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy who was recently diagnosed with Hodgkin lymphoma presents to the emergency department reporting a 48-hour history of fever and cough. He started his first cycle of chemotherapy — doxorubicin, bleomycin, vinblastine, and dacarbazine (ABVD regimen) — 10 days ago.
He has a temperature of 39°C, a heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 120/75 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute. On abdominal examination, he has tenderness to palpation of the right lower quadrant.
He is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A complete blood count shows an absolute neutrophil count of 100 cells per mm3 (reference range, 1900–7600).
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Obtain two sets of blood cultures and chest imaging
Start empiric antibiotics and administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
Administer acetaminophen and reassess body temperature in one hour
Obtain two sets of blood cultures; start empiric antibiotics only if the blood cultures are positive
Obtain two sets of blood cultures, start empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics, and obtain chest and abdominal imaging

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

IDSA guidelines recommend obtaining at least two sets of blood cultures in patients with neutropenic fever. Additional diagnostic evaluation with imaging studies should be guided by signs and symptoms. In this case, the patient has cough, tachypnea, and abdominal pain — and should therefore undergo chest and abdominal imaging. Current guidelines do not specify a preferred chest-imaging modality in patients with neutropenic fever who have respiratory signs and symptoms, but either a chest radiograph or a CT are reasonable options.

B) INCORRECT:

Some of the treatment protocols that place patients at the highest risk for prolonged myelosuppression include granulocyte colony-stimulating factors after the last dose of chemotherapy to shorten the duration of myelosuppression. However, growth factors are not routinely used in most ill patients with fever and neutropenia. Rather, the addition of these medications is reserved for use as an adjunct treatment in patients who have prolonged or complicated febrile neutropenia.

C) INCORRECT:

Acetaminophen with reassessment of body temperature in one hour is not sufficient in a patient with neutropenic fever.

D) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotics and a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation are recommended in the initial management of neutropenic fever, given the potential for rapid progression of an untreated infection in a patient with an impaired immune system.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has fever in the setting of chemotherapy-induced neutropenia, thus raising concern for the possibility of infection. According to guidelines from the Infectious Disease Society of America (IDSA), fever is defined as either a single oral temperature ≥38.3°C or an elevation in temperature to ≥38.0°C for more than one hour, and neutropenia is defined as an absolute neutrophil count that is already <500 cells per mm3 or expected to fall below that valueduring the next 48 hours.

Empiric antibiotics and a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation are recommended in the initial management of neutropenic fever, given the potential for rapid progression of an untreated infection in a patient with an impaired immune system. Infections are documented in 20% to 30% of episodes of neutropenic fever.

IDSA guidelines recommend obtaining at least two sets of blood cultures in patients with neutropenic fever. Additional diagnostic evaluation with imaging studies should be guided by signs and symptoms. In this case, the patient has cough, tachypnea, and abdominal pain — and should therefore undergo chest and abdominal imaging. Current guidelines do not specify a preferred chest-imaging modality in patients with neutropenic fever who have respiratory signs and symptoms, but either a chest radiograph or a CT are reasonable options. Abdominal imaging in a febrile neutropenic patient with abdominal pain is warranted because of the risk for neutropenic enterocolitis (typhlitis). Plain films may be considered to evaluate emergently for free air but have a high false-negative rate; abdominal CT is therefore the preferred imaging modality.

Key learning point: The most appropriate next step for an adolescent undergoing chemotherapy who presents with neutropenic fever is to obtain two sets of blood cultures, start empiric antibiotics, and order imaging studies guided by the patient's specific signs and symptoms.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old man with stage III colon cancer presents to the Emergency Department with a 9-hour history of fever, chills, and malaise. He is receiving his third cycle of adjuvant chemotherapy. He denies cough or urinary symptoms. Physical examination is normal. Blood cultures are pending (see lab results).


Heart rate
96/min


Blood pressure
108/70 mm Hg


Respiratory rate
18/min


Temperature
38.8°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
101 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


WBC
0.4 x 109/L
4.5 - 10.5 x 109/L


Absolute neutrophil count
0.1 x 109/L
1.5 - 8.0 x 109/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administering oral broad-spectrum antibiotics on an outpatient basis
Waiting for blood culture results
Administering intravenous antifungal coverage as first-line therapy
Administering broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics immediately after obtaining blood cultures

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Outpatient oral antibiotics are suitable for low-risk febrile neutropenia. However, this patient has severe neutropenia and systemic symptoms, indicating high risk for sepsis. Inpatient intravenous antibiotics are necessary for rapid therapeutic levels and close monitoring.

B) INCORRECT:

Waiting for blood culture results in febrile neutropenia is contraindicated due to the high risk of rapid infection progression. The patient's severe neutropenia and fever necessitate immediate broad-spectrum antibiotic initiation. Delaying treatment can lead to significant morbidity.

C) INCORRECT:

In febrile neutropenia, initial management focuses on broad-spectrum antibacterial agents due to the high risk of bacterial infections, particularly from Gram-negative organisms. Antifungal therapy is reserved for persistent fever after several days of antibiotics or when fungal infection is suspected.

D) CORRECT:

Febrile neutropenia is an oncologic emergency characterized by fever and a significantly reduced neutrophil count, as seen in this patient with an absolute neutrophil count of 0.1 x 109/L. The compromised immune response increases the risk of rapid, life-threatening infections, often from Gram-negative bacteria like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Immediate administration of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics, initiated within 60 minutes of presentation after obtaining blood cultures, is crucial to prevent infection escalation and associated morbidity. The chosen antibiotic regimen should cover both Gram-negative and Gram-positive organisms, addressing the common pathogens in neutropenic patients.

Key learning point: In cases of febrile neutropenia, especially in patients undergoing chemotherapy, it is crucial to send cultures and start empirical intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics immediately due to the high risk of serious infections.

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics with antipseudomonal coverage
Await blood culture results
Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor without antibiotics
Oral fluoroquinolones and observe as an outpatient

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Febrile neutropenia is an oncologic emergency characterized by fever and significant neutropenia, as seen in this patient with acute myelogenous leukemia. The extremely low white blood cell count and neutrophil percentage indicate a high risk for infections, particularly from gram-negative and pseudomonal bacteria. Immediate initiation of intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics with antipseudomonal coverage is crucial to prevent rapid clinical deterioration and sepsis. This approach aligns with clinical guidelines emphasizing early empiric antibiotic therapy in neutropenic patients with fever.

Key learning point: In patients with febrile neutropenia following chemotherapy, immediate empiric IV antibiotics in a hospital setting are crucial to prevent serious infections and complications.

B) INCORRECT:

While blood cultures are important for identifying pathogens, waiting for results in febrile neutropenia is dangerous. The high risk of sepsis in neutropenic patients necessitates immediate empiric antibiotic therapy. Delaying treatment can lead to life-threatening complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) aids neutrophil recovery but is not a frontline treatment for febrile neutropenia. Immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics are essential to address potential bacterial infections in this high-risk patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral fluoroquinolones are for low-risk febrile neutropenia patients. This patient is high-risk due to hemodynamic instability, high fever, and profound neutropenia. Immediate intravenous antibiotics are necessary for reliable and rapid antimicrobial coverage.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents with fever and chills for the past four hours to the healthcare facility. He has acute myeloid leukemia and completed his first cycle of induction chemotherapy two weeks ago. He reports a mild cough but denies chest pain or abdominal pain. He has no known drug allergies. He appears pale and diaphoretic without obvious respiratory distress. Blood cultures have been drawn (see lab results).


Heart rate
110/min


Blood pressure
90/60 mm Hg


Temperature
38.9°C




Test
Result
Normal Values



Absolute neutrophil count
300/µL
1500 - 8000/µL


Serum chemistry
Normal
Normal



Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Await blood culture results before antibiotics
Intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics
Intravenous granulocyte colony-stimulating factor alone
Chest imaging before antibiotics

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In febrile neutropenia, especially post-chemotherapy, the risk of rapid sepsis progression is high. While blood cultures are essential for pathogen identification, waiting for results delays critical antibiotic therapy. Immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics are necessary to prevent clinical deterioration, as culture results take time and the patient is at high risk due to severe neutropenia.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with acute myeloid leukemia post-induction chemotherapy are at high risk for infections due to severe neutropenia, as indicated by an absolute neutrophil count of 300/µL. Fever in this context suggests a potential sepsis, necessitating immediate intervention. Prompt initiation of intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics is crucial to cover a wide range of bacterial pathogens, including Gram-negative organisms like Pseudomonas aeruginosa. Empirical antibiotic therapy should begin immediately after obtaining blood cultures to prevent rapid infection progression, aligning with guidelines that emphasize early antibiotic administration in febrile neutropenic patients to reduce morbidity and mortality.

Key learning point: In patients with febrile neutropenia, immediate initiation of broad-spectrum IV antibiotics is crucial to prevent severe infections and complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF) stimulates neutrophil production but does not provide immediate antimicrobial coverage. In febrile neutropenia, immediate broad-spectrum antibiotics are necessary due to the risk of rapid bacterial proliferation and sepsis. G-CSF alone is insufficient for acute management as it lacks direct antibacterial properties and takes time to effect neutrophil recovery.

D) INCORRECT:

In a neutropenic patient with signs of systemic infection, such as hypotension and tachycardia, the priority is the prompt initiation of broad-spectrum antibiotics. Although a mild cough may suggest a pulmonary source, neutropenic patients often have atypical radiographic findings. Delaying antibiotics for imaging could allow infection progression, especially given the patient's hemodynamic instability.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents to the ED with fever and mild malaise. She received her last cycle of chemotherapy for breast cancer 9 days ago. She is alert, well-appearing, and tolerating oral intake. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), heart rate 88 bpm, blood pressure 118/72 mm Hg, respiratory rate 16/min, and oxygen saturation 99% on room air. She has no comorbidities, no known drug allergies, normal renal and liver function, and a normal chest x-ray. Laboratory studies show WBC 1,200/mm3 with an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) of 400/mm3. She has not been on antibiotic prophylaxis.
Which of the following is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic regimen for this patient?

choices.text: Give a single IV dose of cefepime, then discharge with oral ciprofloxacin
IV cefepime and admit to hospital
Oral ciprofloxacin plus amoxicillin-clavulanate and discharge home
Oral ciprofloxacin plus clindamycin and discharge home
IV vancomycin and admit to hospital

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who are high-risk (e.g., hemodynamic unstable, have organ dysfunction or are of advanced age) should be admitted for IV therapy. Patients who are stable and low-risk should be treated with an oral regimen from the start. A single dose of IV antibiotics followed by oral antibiotics is not recommended, and monotherapy with ciprofloxacin would not provide adequate gram-positive coverage.

B) INCORRECT:

Cefepime is an appropriate empiric agent for high-risk neutropenic fever, but this patient lacks high-risk features such as hemodynamic instability, organ dysfunction, or advanced age. Intravenous therapy and admission would be inappropriate for this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Correct —This patient is stable, well-appearing, and meets low-risk criteria (e.g. normal vital signs, no organ dysfunction, no comorbidities, solid tumor, age < 60 years). She can be treated as an outpatient with an oral fluoroquinolone (ciprofloxacin or levofloxacin) plus amoxicillin-clavulanate. This is the recommended low-risk regimen when there is no penicillin allergy and no prior fluoroquinolone prophylaxis.

D) INCORRECT:

This combination is used for low-risk patients who are penicillin allergic. This patient is low risk (e.g. normal vital signs, no organ dysfunction, no comorbidities, solid tumor, and aged < 60 years) but she does not have a penicillin allergy.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient does not have high risk features (e.g., hemodynamic instability, organ dysfunction, comorbidities, or advanced age) that would necessitate admission or IV antibiotic therapy. Additionally, vancomycin monotherapy is inadequate because it lacks gram-negative coverage and is reserved as an adjunct when MRSA risk factors are present.
